**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How many children did Memorys sister have by age 16?
Options: A. 1, B. 3, C. 6
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the title of the poem written by Eileen Piri, a 13-year-old girl from Malawi? Options: A. "I'll Marry When I Want", B. "Girl's Rights", C. "Child Marriage", D. "Education for All" Correct Option: A

It was a warrior's cry against child marriage, C. It was a poem about the speaker's own experiences, D. It was a poem about the speaker's sister's experiences Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: If a girl in Malawi is forced to marry before the age of 18, what can she do to protect herself? Options: A. She can seek help from her family and community, B. She can report the incident to the police, C. She can text her local member of Parliament for support, D. She can rely on the local bylaws to protect her Correct Option: C
Question 4: **Analysis**: What are the main reasons why child marriage is a problem in Malawi, according to the speaker? Options: A. Poverty and lack of education, B. Cultural and traditional practices, C. Lack of laws and enforcement, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How can girls and women work together to end child marriage in a generation? Options: A. By relying on male advocates to take action, B. By using technology to spread awareness and mobilize support, C. By pushing for changes in laws and policies, D. By working together with male advocates, using technology, and pushing for changes in laws and policies Correct Option: D
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of the child marriage bill being passed into law in Malawi? Options: A. It is a major step towards ending child marriage, B. It is a setback for girls' rights, C. It is a minor victory for girls' rights, D. It is a law that does not apply to all girls in Malawi Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the current legal marriage age in Malawi? Options: A. 15, B. 18, C. 21, D. 25 Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the speaker, what is the importance of publicizing laws at the local level in Malawi? Options: A. To increase awareness of girls' rights, B. To mobilize support for girls' rights, C. To enforce laws and protect girls' rights, D. To rely on male advocates to take action Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: If a girl in Malawi knows that there are laws that protect her, what can she do to defend herself? Options: A. She can rely on her family and community for support, B. She can text her local member of Parliament for help, C. She can report the incident to the police, D. She can stand up and defend herself because she knows that there is a law that protects her Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Synthesis**: What is the main message of the speaker's speech? Options: A. Girls' rights are not important, B. Child marriage is a major problem in Malawi, C. Girls can end child marriage in a generation, D. Laws are not important in protecting girls' rights Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Warning: Match index out of range for Ground Truth Set 17, Question 3
Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Memory helped her community put a rule in place that no girl could be forced to be married before what age?
Options: A. 15, B. 16, C. 18
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 6
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How old was Memorys sister when she got pregnant?
Options: A. 11, B. 13, C. 15
Correct Option: A

Question 1: **Knowledge**: What is the title of the poem written by Eileen Piri, a 13-year-old girl from Malawi? Options: A. "I'll Marry When I Want", B. "Girl's Rights", C. "Child Marriage", D. "Education for All" Correct Option: A
Question 2: **Comprehension**: According to the speaker, what was the significance of Eileen Piri's poem "I'll Marry When I Want"? Options: A. It was a poem about the importance of education, B. It was a warrior's cry against child marriage, C. It was a poem about the speaker's own experiences, D. It was a poem about the speaker's sister's experiences Correct Option: B
Question 3: **Application**: If a girl in Malawi is forced to marry before the age of 18, what can she do to protect herself? Options: A. She can seek help from her family and community, B. She can report the incident to the police, C. She can text her local member of Parliament for support, D. She can rely on the local bylaws to protect her Correct Option: C
Question 4: **Analysis**: What are the main reasons why child marriage is a problem in Malawi, according to the speaker? Options: A. Poverty and lack of education, B. Cultural and traditional practices, C. Lack of laws and enforcement, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: **Synthesis**: How can girls and women work together to end child marriage in a generation? Options: A. By relying on male advocates to take action, B. By using technology to spread awareness and mobilize support, C. By pushing for changes in laws and policies, D. By working together with male advocates, using technology, and pushing for changes in laws and policies Correct Option: D
Question 6: **Evaluation**: What is the significance of the child marriage bill being passed into law in Malawi? Options: A. It is a major step towards ending child marriage, B. It is a setback for girls' rights, C. It is a minor victory for girls' rights, D. It is a law that does not apply to all girls in Malawi Correct Option: A
Question 7: **Knowledge**: What is the current legal marriage age in Malawi? Options: A. 15, B. 18, C. 21, D. 25 Correct Option: B
Question 8: **Comprehension**: According to the speaker, what is the importance of publicizing laws at the local level in Malawi? Options: A. To increase awareness of girls' rights, B. To mobilize support for girls' rights, C. To enforce laws and protect girls' rights, D. To rely on male advocates to take action Correct Option: C
Question 9: **Application**: If a girl in Malawi knows that there are laws that protect her, what can she do to defend herself? Options: A. She can rely on her family and community for support, B. She can text her local member of Parliament for help, C. She can report the incident to the police, D. She can stand up and defend herself because she knows that there is a law that protects her Correct Option: D
Question 10: **Synthesis**: What is the main message of the speaker's speech? Options: A. Girls' rights are not important, B. Child marriage is a major problem in Malawi, C. Girls can end child marriage in a generation, D. Laws are not important in protecting girls' rights Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 17, Question 7
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. As it is in my culture, once you reach puberty stage, you are supposed to go
to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,
she ended up being pregnant. Today, she's only 16 years old and she has three children. Her first marriage did not survive, nor did her second marriage. On the other side, there is this girl. She's amazing. (Laughter) (Applause) I call her amazing because she is. She's very fabulous. That girl is me. (Laughter) When I was 13 years old, I was told, you are grown up, you have now reached of age, you're supposed to go
to the initiation camp. I was like, "What? I'm not going to go
to the initiation camps." You know what the women said to me? "You are a stupid girl. Stubborn. You do not respect the traditions
of our society, of our community." I said no because I knew
where I was going. I knew what I wanted in life. I had a lot of dreams as a young girl. I wanted to get well educated, to find a decent job in the future. I was imagining myself as a lawyer, seated on that big chair. Those were the imaginations that were going through my mind every day. And I knew that one day, I would contribute something,
a little something to my community. But every day after refusing, women would tell me, "Look at you, you're all grown up.
Your little sister has a baby. What about you?" That was the music
that I was hearing every day, and that is the music
that girls hear every day when they don't do something
that the community needs them to do. When I compared the two stories
between me and my sister, I said, "Why can't I do something? Why can't I change something
that has happened for a long time in our community?" That was when I called other girls just like my sister, who have children, who have been in class but they have
forgotten how to read and write. I said, "Come on, we can 
remind each other how to read and write again, how to hold the pen,
how to read, to hold the book." It was a great time I had with them. Nor did I just learn a little about them, but they were able to tell me
their personal stories, what they were facing every day as young mothers. That was when I was like, 'Why can't we take all these things
that are happening to us and present them and tell our mothers,
our traditional leaders, that these are the wrong things?" It was a scary thing to do, because these traditional leaders, they are already accustomed to the things that have been there for ages. A hard thing to change, but a good thing to try. So we tried. It was very hard, but we pushed. And I'm here to say that in my community, it was the first community after girls pushed so hard to our traditional leader, and our leader stood up for us
and said no girl has to be married before the age of 18. (Applause) In my community, that was the first time a community, they had to call the bylaws, the first bylaw that protected girls in our community. We did not stop there. We forged ahead. We were determined to fight for girls
not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members
of Parliament were entering, we were telling them,
"Would you please support the bill?" And we don't have
much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal
marriage age, from 15 to 18. (Applause) It's a good thing to know
that the bill passed, but let me tell you this: There are countries where 18
is the legal marriage age, but don't we hear cries
of women and girls every day? Every day, girls' lives
are being wasted away. This is high time for leaders
to honor their commitment. In honoring this commitment, it means keeping girls' issues
at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

Correct Option: B

**Transcript**:
I'll begin today by sharing a poem written by my friend from Malawi, Eileen Piri. Eileen is only 13 years old, but when we were going through
the collection of poetry that we wrote, I found her poem so interesting, so motivating. So I'll read it to you. She entitled her poem
"I'll Marry When I Want." (Laughter) "I'll marry when I want. My mother can't force me to marry. My father cannot force me to marry. My uncle, my aunt, my brother or sister, cannot force me to marry. No one in the world can force me to marry. I'll marry when I want. Even if you beat me, even if you chase me away, even if you do anything bad to me, I'll marry when I want. I'll marry when I want, but not before I am well educated, and not before I am all grown up. I'll marry when I want." This poem might seem odd, written by a 13-year-old girl, but where I and Eileen come from, this poem, which I have just read to you, is a warrior's cry. I am from Malawi. Malawi is one of the poorest countries, very poor, where gender equality is questionable. Growing up in that country, I couldn't make my own choices in life. I couldn't even explore personal opportunities in life. I will tell you a story of two different girls, two beautiful girls. These girls grew up under the same roof. They were eating the same food. Sometimes, they would share clothes, and even shoes. But their lives ended up differently, in two different paths. The other girl is my little sister. My little sister was only 11 years old when she got pregnant. It's a hurtful thing. Not only did it hurt her, even me. I was going through a hard time as well. to initiation camps. In these initiation camps, you are taught how
to sexually please a man. There is this special day, which they call "Very Special Day" where a man who is hired
by the community comes to the camp and sleeps with the little girls. Imagine the trauma that these young girls go through every day. Most girls end up pregnant. They even contract HIV and AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. For my little sister,

not just in my community, but even in other communities. When the child marriage bill
was being presented in February, we were there at the Parliament house. Every day, when the members

much technology like here, but we have our small phones. So we said, "Why can't we get 
their numbers and text them?" So we did that. It was a good thing. (Applause) So when the bill passed,
we texted them back, "Thank you for supporting the bill." (Laughter) And when the bill was signed
by the president, making it into law, it was a plus. Now, in Malawi, 18 is the legal

at heart every time. We don't have to be subjected as second, but they have to know that women,
as we are in this room, we are not just women,
we are not just girls, we are extraordinary. We can do more. And another thing for Malawi, and not just Malawi but other countries: The laws which are there, you know how a law is not a law
until it is enforced? The law which has just recently passed and the laws that in other countries
have been there, they need to be publicized
at the local level, at the community level, where girls' issues are very striking. Girls face issues, difficult issues,
at the community level every day. So if these young girls know
that there are laws that protect them, they will be able to stand up
and defend themselves because they will know that
there is a law that protects them. And another thing I would say is that girls' voices and women's voices are beautiful, they are there, but we cannot do this alone. Male advocates, they have to jump in, to step in and work together. It's a collective work. What we need is what girls elsewhere need: good education, and above all,
not to marry whilst 11. And furthermore, I know that together, we can transform the legal, the cultural and political framework that denies girls of their rights. I am standing here today and declaring that we can
end child marriage in a generation. This is the moment where a girl and a girl,
and millions of girls worldwide, will be able to say, "I will marry when I want." (Applause) Thank you. (Applause)

Options: A. 15, B. 16, C. 18
Correct Option: C

Question 10: **Synthesis**: What is the main message of the speaker's speech? Options: A. Girls' rights are not important, B. Child marriage is a major problem in Malawi, C. Girls can end child marriage in a generation, D. Laws are not important in protecting girls' rights Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 7: Knowledge**: What is the current legal marriage age in Malawi? Options: A. 15, B. 18, C. 21, D. 25 Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a wildfire rages through
the grasslands, three lions and three wildebeest
flee for their lives. To escape the inferno, they must cross over to the left bank
of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens
to be a raft nearby. It can carry up to two animals at a time, and needs as least one lion
or wildebeest on board to row it across the river. There's just one problem. If the lions ever outnumber the
wildebeest on either side of the river, even for a moment, their instincts will kick in,
and the results won't be pretty. That includes the animals in the boat
when it's on a given side of the river. What's the fastest way for all six animals
to get across without the lions stopping for dinner? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 If you feel stuck on a problem like this, try listing all the decisions you can make
at each point, and the consequences each choice
leads to. For instance, there are five options
for who goes across first: one wildebeest, one lion, two wildebeest, two lions, or one of each. If one animal goes alone, it'll just have to come straight back. And if two wildebeest cross first, the remaining one will immediately
get eaten. So those options are all out. Sending two lions, or one of each animal, can actually both lead to solutions
in the same number of moves. For the sake of time,
we'll focus on the second one. One of each animal crosses. Now, if the wildebeest stays 
and the lion returns, there will be three lions
on the right bank. Bad news for the two remaining wildebeest. So we need to have the lion
stay on the left bank and the wildebeest go back to the right. Now we have the same five options, but with one lion 
already on the left bank. If two wildebeest go,
the one that stays will get eaten, and if one of each animal goes, the wildebeest on the raft
will be outnumbered as soon as it reaches the other side. So that's a dead end, which means that at the third crossing, only the two lions can go. One gets dropped off, leaving two lions on the left bank. The third lion takes the raft back to
the right bank where the wildebeest are waiting. What now? Well, since we've got two lions waiting
on the left bank, the only option is for two wildebeest
to cross. Next, there's no sense in two wildebeest
going back, since that just reverses the last step. And if two lions go back, they'll outnumber the wildebeest
on the right bank. So one lion and one wildebeest
take the raft back leaving us with one of each animal
on the left bank and two of each on the right. Again, there's no point in sending 
the lion-wildebeest pair back, so the next trip should be either
a pair of lions or a pair of wildebeest. If the lions go, they'd eat the wildebeest
on the left, so they stay, and the two wildebeest cross instead. Now we're quite close because the
wildebeest are all where they need to be with safety in numbers. All that's left is for that one lion
to raft back and bring his fellow lions over
one by one. That makes eleven trips total, the smallest number needed
to get everyone across safely. The solution that involves sending both
lions on the first step works similarly, and also takes eleven crossings. The six animals escape unharmed
from the fire just in time and begin their new lives 
across the river. Of course, now that the danger's passed, it remains to be seen how long their
unlikely alliance will last.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why cant the first move be two wildebeest going across?
Options: A. The third wildebeest that doesnt go will get eaten by the three lions, B. The crocodile might eat them, C. The wildebeest might not get along, D. One animal going across is the most efficient move
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary obstacle that the lions and wildebeest face in crossing the river? Options: A. The presence of crocodiles in the river, B. The limited capacity of the raft, C. The lions' instincts to eat the wildebeest, D. The river's strong currents Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the minimum number of animals required on the raft to row it across the river? Options: A. 1, B. 2, C. 3, D. 4 Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the consequence of having two wildebeest cross the river first? Options: A. The remaining wildebeest will be safe, B. The remaining wildebeest will be eaten, C. The lions will be safe, D. The wildebeest will outnumber the lions Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the solution that involves sending both lions on the first step? Options: A. It takes 10 crossings to get everyone across safely, B. It takes 11 crossings to get everyone across safely, C. It involves sending one lion and one wildebeest on the first step, D. It involves sending two wildebeest on the first step Correct Option: B
Question 5: According to the transcript, what is the reason for not sending two wildebeest back to the right bank after the third crossing? Options: A. Because the lions will outnumber the wildebeest, B. Because the wildebeest will be safe, C. Because the lions will be safe, D. Because the river's currents are strong Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is the consequence of sending two lions back to the right bank after the third crossing? Options: A. The wildebeest will be safe, B. The lions will outnumber the wildebeest, C. The wildebeest will be eaten, D. The lions will be safe Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the solution that involves sending one lion and one wildebeest on the first step? Options: A. It takes 10 crossings to get everyone across safely, B. It takes 11 crossings to get everyone across safely, C. It involves sending two lions on the first step, D. It involves sending two wildebeest on the first step Correct Option: B
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the total number of trips required to get everyone across safely? Options: A. 10, B. 11, C. 12, D. 13 Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the reason for not sending the lion-wildebeest pair back after the fifth crossing? Options: A. Because the lions will outnumber the wildebeest, B. Because the wildebeest will be safe, C. Because the lions will be safe, D. Because the river's currents are strong Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the outcome of the six animals crossing the river safely? Options: A. They will be eaten by the crocodiles, B. They will be safe and start their new lives across the river, C. They will be outnumbered by the lions, D. They will be unable to cross the river Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to understand the consequence of having two wildebeest cross the river first. The options for Question 3 are also similar to the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (B) stating that the remaining wildebeest will be eaten. 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 3.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 18, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
As a wildfire rages through
the grasslands, three lions and three wildebeest
flee for their lives. To escape the inferno, they must cross over to the left bank
of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens
to be a raft nearby. It can carry up to two animals at a time, and needs as least one lion
or wildebeest on board to row it across the river. There's just one problem. If the lions ever outnumber the
wildebeest on either side of the river, even for a moment, their instincts will kick in,
and the results won't be pretty. That includes the animals in the boat
when it's on a given side of the river. What's the fastest way for all six animals
to get across without the lions stopping for dinner? Pause here if you want 
to figure it out for yourself. Answer in: 3 Answer in: 2 Answer in: 1 If you feel stuck on a problem like this, try listing all the decisions you can make
at each point, and the consequences each choice
leads to. For instance, there are five options
for who goes across first: one wildebeest, one lion, two wildebeest, two lions, or one of each. If one animal goes alone, it'll just have to come straight back. And if two wildebeest cross first, the remaining one will immediately
get eaten. So those options are all out. Sending two lions, or one of each animal, can actually both lead to solutions
in the same number of moves. For the sake of time,
we'll focus on the second one. One of each animal crosses. Now, if the wildebeest stays 
and the lion returns, there will be three lions
on the right bank. Bad news for the two remaining wildebeest. So we need to have the lion
stay on the left bank and the wildebeest go back to the right. Now we have the same five options, but with one lion 
already on the left bank. If two wildebeest go,
the one that stays will get eaten, and if one of each animal goes, the wildebeest on the raft
will be outnumbered as soon as it reaches the other side. So that's a dead end, which means that at the third crossing, only the two lions can go. One gets dropped off, leaving two lions on the left bank. The third lion takes the raft back to
the right bank where the wildebeest are waiting. What now? Well, since we've got two lions waiting
on the left bank, the only option is for two wildebeest
to cross. Next, there's no sense in two wildebeest
going back, since that just reverses the last step. And if two lions go back, they'll outnumber the wildebeest
on the right bank. So one lion and one wildebeest
take the raft back leaving us with one of each animal
on the left bank and two of each on the right. Again, there's no point in sending 
the lion-wildebeest pair back, so the next trip should be either
a pair of lions or a pair of wildebeest. If the lions go, they'd eat the wildebeest
on the left, so they stay, and the two wildebeest cross instead. Now we're quite close because the
wildebeest are all where they need to be with safety in numbers. All that's left is for that one lion
to raft back and bring his fellow lions over
one by one. That makes eleven trips total, the smallest number needed
to get everyone across safely. The solution that involves sending both
lions on the first step works similarly, and also takes eleven crossings. The six animals escape unharmed
from the fire just in time and begin their new lives 
across the river. Of course, now that the danger's passed, it remains to be seen how long their
unlikely alliance will last.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: After the wildebeest rafts back (second crossing), which animal(s) now raft from the right side of the river to the left side (third crossing)?
Options: A. One wildebeest, B. Two wildebeest, C. Two lions, D. One lion
Correct Option: C

of a crocodile-infested river. Fortunately, there happens

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is a map of Yellowstone National Park. For the most part the park is in Wyoming, but it extends a bit into Montana and Idaho. This little 50 square miles section in Idaho is what concerns us. It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram. You have the right to demand jury from that middle area, where the state in which you committed the crime, that's Idaho, overlaps with the judicial jurisdiction where you committed the crime: the Wyoming district that has jurisdiction over Yellowstone National Park. And here's the problem: "nobody lives there. There's there's no way for them to give you a trial and so I argue they should have to let you go." This could also happen in the Montana portion of the park, except a few dozen people do live there, so a jury could theoretically be called. Kalt has proposed numerous solutions to Congress to fix the loophole, but they have yet to act. "All they have to do is redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana and if they do that this all goes away." So if you're planning a gathering of your adversaries, exes, and debtors, maybe try Yosemite.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Yellowstone National Park is mostly in which state?
Options: A. Wyoming, B. Montana, C. Idaho
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the 50 square miles section in Idaho that is part of Yellowstone National Park and is often referred to as the "zone of death"? Options: A. The Vicinage Clause, B. The Perfect Crime, C. The zone of death, D. Yellowstone's Idaho region Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why the zone of death is considered a loophole in the Constitution? Options: A. It is a result of a conflict between federal and state laws, B. It is a result of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States, C. It is a result of a lack of jurisdiction in the state of Idaho, D. It is a result of a lack of jurisdiction in the state of Wyoming Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to law professor Brian C. Kalt, what happens if someone is caught for a crime they committed in the 50 square mile Idaho region of Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. They are immediately taken to trial in Idaho, B. They are immediately taken to trial in Wyoming, C. They are brought to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, D. They are brought to the state where the crime was committed Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution, where should the trial take place for someone who committed a crime in the zone of death? Options: A. In the state where the crime was committed, B. In the state where the defendant resides, C. In the state where the defendant was arrested, D. In the federal court Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the name of the clause in the 6th amendment that requires a jury to be from the state and district where the crime was committed? Options: A. The Vicinage Clause, B. The Perfect Crime, C. The Right to a Fair Trial, D. The Right to a Speedy Trial Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to law professor Brian C. Kalt, what is the problem with the zone of death? Options: A. There is no problem, it is a perfectly valid legal concept, B. There is no way for the defendant to receive a fair trial, C. There is no way for the defendant to receive a speedy trial, D. There is no way for the defendant to receive a trial at all Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one of the proposed solutions to the loophole in the zone of death, as proposed by law professor Brian C. Kalt? Options: A. To redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana, B. To create a new federal district court to handle cases from the zone of death, C. To abolish the 6th amendment, D. D: To ignore the loophole and hope it goes away Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the name of the paper written by law professor Brian C. Kalt that discusses the loophole in the zone of death? Options: A. The Perfect Crime, B. The Zone of Death, C. The Vicinage Clause, D. The 6th Amendment Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the location of the hub of the district court of Wyoming, where someone who committed a crime in the zone of death would be brought to? Options: A. Cheyenne, B. Yellowstone National Park, C. Idaho Falls, D. Jackson Hole Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the name of the park where law professor Brian C. Kalt suggests that someone planning a gathering of adversaries, exes, and debtors might want to try instead of Yellowstone? Options: A. Yosemite, B. Grand Canyon, C. Zion National Park, D. Glacier National Park Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the content and intent of the questions, the most similar generated MCQ would be one that discusses the geographical location of Yellowstone National Park.

While there isn't a direct match, Question 1 mentions the 50 square miles section in Idaho that is part of Yellowstone National Park. However, it does not directly address the primary location of the park.

Given the options, I would say that none of the generated MCQs closely match the ground truth MCQ. However, if I had to choose one based on the content, I would say that Question 1 is the closest, but it's still not a good match.

If I had to provide an index, I would say: 1

However, I would like to emphasize that none of the generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ, and Question 1 is only a weak match. A better-generated MCQ would be one that directly asks about the primary location of Yellowstone National Park, with options that include Wyoming, Montana, and Idaho.

To redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana, B. To create a new federal district court to handle cases from the zone of death, C. To abolish the 6th amendment, D. D: To ignore the loophole and hope it goes away Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the name of the paper written by law professor Brian C. Kalt that discusses the loophole in the zone of death? Options: A. The Perfect Crime, B. The Zone of Death, C. The Vicinage Clause, D. The 6th Amendment Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the location of the hub of the district court of Wyoming, where someone who committed a crime in the zone of death would be brought to? Options: A. Cheyenne, B. Yellowstone National Park, C. Idaho Falls, D. Jackson Hole Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the name of the park where law professor Brian C. Kalt suggests that someone planning a gathering of adversaries, exes, and debtors might want to try instead of Yellowstone? Options: A. Yosemite, B. Grand Canyon, C. Zion National Park, D. Glacier National Park Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
This is a map of Yellowstone National Park. For the most part the park is in Wyoming, but it extends a bit into Montana and Idaho. This little 50 square miles section in Idaho is what concerns us. It's called the zone of death, because of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States. If someone were to exploit that loophole they might be able to get away with murder. Yellowstone was established in 1872 before Wyoming, Idaho, and Montana joined the Union. It's federal land and always has been, but federal land across the U.S. is split up and divided into its corresponding state district courts. Except for Yellowstone. And this is where the loophole begins. Law professor Brian C. Kalt points out in his 2005 paper, "The Perfect Crime", that Yellowstone National Park was assigned fully to Wyoming's district court, even though small portions fall into Montana and Idaho. "Unlike every other district, the district of Wyoming includes land in other states." So Kalt asks the question: what happens if you're caught for a crime you committed in that 50 square mile Idaho region of the park? The first thing law enforcement would do is bring you to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, because the crime technically happened within Wyoming's jurisdiction. But Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution says that the trial should happen in the state where you committed the crime. If you're a savvy murderer you'll invoke your right to a trial in Idaho. So they bring you back to Idaho no big deal. "In the sixth amendment they said that they would require local juries and the language they use is that the jury has to be from the state and district where the crime was committed." This is called the Vicinage Clause. That leaves you with a sort of venn diagram. You have the right to demand jury from that middle area, where the state in which you committed the crime, that's Idaho, overlaps with the judicial jurisdiction where you committed the crime: the Wyoming district that has jurisdiction over Yellowstone National Park. And here's the problem: "nobody lives there. There's there's no way for them to give you a trial and so I argue they should have to let you go." This could also happen in the Montana portion of the park, except a few dozen people do live there, so a jury could theoretically be called. Kalt has proposed numerous solutions to Congress to fix the loophole, but they have yet to act. "All they have to do is redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana and if they do that this all goes away." So if you're planning a gathering of your adversaries, exes, and debtors, maybe try Yosemite.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In which state does the Zone of Death belong?
Options: A. Montana, B. Idaho, C. Wyoming
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the 50 square miles section in Idaho that is part of Yellowstone National Park and is often referred to as the "zone of death"? Options: A. The Vicinage Clause, B. The Perfect Crime, C. The zone of death, D. Yellowstone's Idaho region Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the primary reason why the zone of death is considered a loophole in the Constitution? Options: A. It is a result of a conflict between federal and state laws, B. It is a result of a loophole that exists in the Constitution of the United States, C. It is a result of a lack of jurisdiction in the state of Idaho, D. It is a result of a lack of jurisdiction in the state of Wyoming Correct Option: B
Question 3: According to law professor Brian C. Kalt, what happens if someone is caught for a crime they committed in the 50 square mile Idaho region of Yellowstone National Park? Options: A. They are immediately taken to trial in Idaho, B. They are immediately taken to trial in Wyoming, C. They are brought to Cheyenne, the hub of the district court of Wyoming, D. They are brought to the state where the crime was committed Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to Article 3 Section 2 of the United States Constitution, where should the trial take place for someone who committed a crime in the zone of death? Options: A. In the state where the crime was committed, B. In the state where the defendant resides, C. In the state where the defendant was arrested, D. In the federal court Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the name of the clause in the 6th amendment that requires a jury to be from the state and district where the crime was committed? Options: A. The Vicinage Clause, B. The Perfect Crime, C. The Right to a Fair Trial, D. The Right to a Speedy Trial Correct Option: A
Question 6: According to law professor Brian C. Kalt, what is the problem with the zone of death? Options: A. There is no problem, it is a perfectly valid legal concept, B. There is no way for the defendant to receive a fair trial, C. There is no way for the defendant to receive a speedy trial, D. There is no way for the defendant to receive a trial at all Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is one of the proposed solutions to the loophole in the zone of death, as proposed by law professor Brian C. Kalt? Options: A. To redraw the district line so that the district of Wyoming is Wyoming, the district of Idaho is Idaho, and the district of Montana is Montana, B. To create a new federal district court to handle cases from the zone of death, C. To abolish the 6th amendment, D. D: To ignore the loophole and hope it goes away Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the name of the paper written by law professor Brian C. Kalt that discusses the loophole in the zone of death? Options: A. The Perfect Crime, B. The Zone of Death, C. The Vicinage Clause, D. The 6th Amendment Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the location of the hub of the district court of Wyoming, where someone who committed a crime in the zone of death would be brought to? Options: A. Cheyenne, B. Yellowstone National Park, C. Idaho Falls, D. Jackson Hole Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the name of the park where law professor Brian C. Kalt suggests that someone planning a gathering of adversaries, exes, and debtors might want to try instead of Yellowstone? Options: A. Yosemite, B. Grand Canyon, C. Zion National Park, D. Glacier National Park Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

Question 1: What is the name of the 50 square miles section in Idaho that is part of Yellowstone National Park and is often referred to as the "zone of death"? 

However, this question does not exactly match the ground truth MCQ. A more similar question would be one that asks about the state in which the "Zone of Death" belongs.

A more suitable match can be found in the options of Question 3, but the question itself does not match.

If we were to choose the most similar question from the given options, it would be Question 1, but with the understanding that it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

However, if we were to recreate a question from the given transcript that matches the ground truth MCQ, it would be:

Question: In which state is the 50 square miles section known as the "Zone of Death" located?
Options: A. Montana, B. Idaho, C. Wyoming

And this would match with the content of Question 1 and the options of the ground truth MCQ.
